misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted problem requirements (implemented different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a physics-style average acceleration calculator instead of the requested program to sum even numbers from 5 integer inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that reads v0, v1, and t, computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires a program that reads exactly 5 integers from the user, checks each one to see if it is even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulates the sum of only the even numbers, and prints that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Only three double values are read instead of five integers.
No loop to process 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers.
Output reports 'average acceleration' rather than 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different exercise about computing average acceleration, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the specific problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the processing steps (looping 5 times, checking evenness with n % 2 == 0), and the required output (sum of even numbers). Then design your variables and control structures specifically around those requirements.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure and naming in the program (v0, v1, t, average acceleration) clearly correspond to a different known textbook problem and do not match any part of the stated task.

evidence.note: All variable names, the prompt, and the formula correspond to an acceleration problem, with no code related to reading 5 integers, checking evenness, or summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code calculating average acceleration based on inputs for initial velocity, final velocity, and time. This submission does not attempt to solve the assigned problem, which requires reading five integers, using loops, and summing only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused this assignment with a different programming task (e.g., a physics calculation problem) and believes the submitted code fulfills the requirements of Q1.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires using a loop to read five integers, employing the modulus operator (%) within an if-statement to check for even numbers, and using an accumulator variable to store the final sum.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration, not a sum.
Only 3 inputs are read, not 5.
Inputs are of type 'double' instead of 'int'.
No loop structure is used for multiple inputs.
The class name and input prompt are incorrect for the assignment.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or confusing the problem statement for Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt again. The required task is 'Sum of Even Numbers', which involves reading integers, using iteration (a loop), and conditional filtering based on parity.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to solving an unrelated physics problem, demonstrating a complete failure to address the requirements of Q1.

evidence.note: The class name highlights the focus on acceleration, not summing even numbers.
The input prompt asks for three velocity/time inputs instead of the five integers required by the task.
The core calculation is the formula for average acceleration, not the accumulation of even integers.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem - acceleration calculation instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers, the student wrote a program that reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics acceleration problem rather than the assigned sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), summing only the even numbers, and displaying the result.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program performs acceleration calculation instead of even number filtering
Output message says 'The average acceleration is' instead of 'Sum of even numbers:'
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the assignment, copied code from a different problem, or did not understand the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. You need to: (1) Read 5 integers using a loop, (2) Check each with n % 2 == 0 to see if it's even, (3) Add even numbers to a running sum, (4) Print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: With complete certainty, this is a different problem entirely. The code solves a physics acceleration calculation problem, not the assigned sum of even numbers problem. This is not ambiguous - the problem statement and sample run are clear.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 doubles for an acceleration problem instead of 5 integers for sum of even numbers

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeElapsed;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers; no modulo check or accumulator logic

evidence.snippet:
Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.

Sample run:
Enter 5 integers: 3 8 2 7 4
Sum of even numbers: 14
evidence.note: Assignment clearly requires 5 integers and sum of even numbers, not acceleration calculation

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving a different problem)
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers and computing the sum of the even numbers, the student wrote a program that reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the actual assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time, even though the prompt asks for summing even numbers from five integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop and conditional checks to identify the even numbers, accumulate their sum, and then print the sum of those even numbers. Any other problem (such as calculating acceleration) is not addressing the assignment.
symptoms: Program input prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
Program computes (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeElapsed instead of summing even numbers.
Output message reports average acceleration rather than the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing code from a different exercise or not carefully reading and mapping the current problem statement to the required program behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the question and break it down into explicit steps: (1) read 5 integers, (2) for each number, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) if even, add it to a running sum, (4) after processing all 5 numbers, print the sum. Start with pseudocode for these steps before writing Java code.
related_concepts: Use of loops and conditionals for data processing
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around calculating average acceleration and has no elements (loop, even check, sum) related to the requested task of summing even numbers, which strongly indicates the problem requirements were misinterpreted or ignored.

evidence.note: The prompt, variables, calculation, and output all correspond to an average acceleration problem, not to reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration using three variables: v0, v1, and t) instead of the requested task (reading 5 integers and summing the even ones). This indicates a severe misunderstanding of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment required calculating acceleration, or they submitted code for a previous/different exercise.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading exactly 5 integers, iterating through them, checking for evenness, and accumulating the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code logic calculates acceleration.
Prompts for 3 inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of 5.
Uses double variables for inputs instead of integers.
Fails to implement looping, conditional checks, or summation logic required for the assigned task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt, submitting incorrect code, or confusing this assignment with another one (such as a kinematics exercise).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the assignment Q1: Sum of Even Numbers. Your current code calculates acceleration. You need to implement a loop to read 5 numbers, use the modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers, and use an accumulator variable to store the total sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is completely unrelated to the assigned task (summing even numbers), demonstrating a critical failure to address the core problem requirements.

evidence.note: The class name itself suggests a different purpose.
The code explicitly implements the acceleration calculation pattern, requiring 3 unrelated double inputs, instead of 5 integer inputs for summation.

misconceptions.name: Using 'double' instead of 'int' for integer inputs
misconceptions.description: The requirements specify reading integers, but the student chose to read inputs using `nextDouble()`, treating them as floating-point numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student defaults to `double` for input, perhaps believing it is safer or not noting the semantic difference for the context of 'even numbers' (which typically applies to integers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Since the task involves checking for 'even numbers' using the modulo operator (which is standard for integers), the inputs must be read as `int` using `nextInt()`.
symptoms: Use of 'nextDouble()' when 'nextInt()' is required.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to data type specifications in the assignment, or misunderstanding the difference between integers and floating-point numbers in the context of input operations.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement. When dealing with whole numbers like counts or even/odd checks, use the `int` data type and the `nextInt()` method.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `nextDouble()` for all inputs, violating the integer requirement of the problem.

evidence.note: All inputs are read as doubles.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Solving Wrong Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment requirements and submitted a solution to an entirely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment requires calculating average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t with three inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking each for evenness using (n % 2 == 0), and accumulating/printing the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Calculates and displays average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic for checking even/odd
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have solved a different assignment by mistake, submitted wrong file, or fundamentally misread the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the assignment requirements again. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers using a loop, (2) Check if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) Accumulate a sum of only even numbers, (4) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submission is solving a physically different problem (acceleration calculation) with different input requirements (3 doubles vs 5 integers) and different output (acceleration vs sum of even numbers). This is unambiguously the wrong assignment.

evidence.note: Prompts for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers. This indicates student is solving the wrong problem.

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeElapsed;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: Calculates and prints acceleration (physics formula) instead of sum of even numbers. No loop, no modulo check, no accumulation.
